message.content: A carbonara is a popular Italian pasta dish made with a sauce consisting of eggs, cheese, bacon or pancetta, and black pepper. The dish has a creamy texture with a slightly salty and smoky taste. The sauce is typically thick and coats the pasta noodles evenly. The dish can have a light yellow or creamy white color, depending on the type of cheese used. Carbonara can be found in most Italian restaurants, and it's a common dish you can make at home. The dish originates from Rome, Italy, and it's frequently enjoyed as a lunch or dinner entree. Some variations may include additional ingredients, such as peas or mushrooms.
